I haven’t shared a lot about the work I am doing….But I have added a hiring banner and I am  really excited about the work, the culture, the perks. It’s been a minute where I am learning on the job every day not just by doing the work in front of me but what others around me are doing.It’s such a special engineering culture that welcomes improvements, for instance the onboarding is project based and builds on each part, and you can go from zero to field production fairly quick if you are curious, confident, and a tinkerer.It’s also refreshing to be around people who are super comfortable explaining things, and staying late is not encouraged, you need a really good reason to stay late. Because you can make up time from home or gradually over time.It’s not for everyone though… I have been here 6 weeks already and haven’t been able to refer anyone and I know people who would love it and thrive and be great contributors.we are looking to double in size this year, poised to capitalize on the current market disruptions.Perks include fun lunches where not just good food but good company and learning about new people or people you may not be working with directly.🏓 leaderboard [on the down-low]Really unusual snacks lots of drink options, someone noticed I was getting drinks elsewhere and all of sudden said drink became a staple. Free gym membership on site.Everyone has an office. Engineers all have same title. It’s all full stack, we are simply DevOps.

Username: Africa ProCloud Institute Africa ProCloud Institute
Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. If you’re looking to start or advance your career in cloud infrastructure and DevOps, visit https://lnkd.in/gt6VMrbg to learn more.By investing in your education and mastering DevOps, you position yourself at the forefront of a growing field with endless opportunities.

Username: Africa ProCloud Institute Africa ProCloud Institute
Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. If you’re looking to start or advance your career in cloud infrastructure and DevOps, visit https://lnkd.in/gt6VMrbg to learn more.By investing in your education and mastering DevOps, you position yourself at the forefront of a growing field with endless opportunities.

Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? Share below! 👇 hashtag#CyberSecurityCareer hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#CyberSecTips hashtag#CareerGrowth) hashtag#cybersecurity hashtag#cybersecuritytraining hashtag#cybersecurityawareness hashtag#digitaltransformation hashtag#technology hashtag#digitalinclusion hashtag#innovation hashtag#informationsecurity

Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. If you’re looking to start or advance your career in cloud infrastructure and DevOps, visit https://lnkd.in/gt6VMrbg to learn more.By investing in your education and mastering DevOps, you position yourself at the forefront of a growing field with endless opportunities.

Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? Username: Africa ProCloud Institute Africa ProCloud Institute
Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? 𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗔𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗘𝗻𝘁𝗿𝘆-𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗥𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀! 🚫We talk a lot about fixing hiring practices, yet one of the biggest flaws remains: requiring years of experience for entry-level roles.An entry-level role means just that—the starting point in someone’s career. If a position requires 2, 3, or even 7 years of experience, it’s not entry-level.Why This Needs to Change:✅ 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗱𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗯𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 and skills that can drive innovation.✅ 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 = 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 – Someone with years in the industry may not necessarily have the skills you need.✅ 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 – Labelling a job “entry-level” but demanding experience wastes applicants’ time and hurts your employer brand.✅ 𝗜𝘁 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 – Many qualified candidates self-reject because they don’t meet unrealistic requirements.🔹 Instead, set clear, realistic expectations: Entry-level = 0-1 year of experience.🔹 Focus on potential, skills, and learning ability rather than just past experience.🚀 If companies truly want to build strong, diverse, and future-ready teams, they need to 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆, 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆.Have you come across unrealistic job postings? Drop them in the comments! Let’s push for 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀. hashtag#EntryLevel hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#EntryLevelJobs hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#HRCommunity hashtag#WorkplaceInnovation hashtag#HiringTrends

Username: Africa ProCloud Institute Africa ProCloud Institute
Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. If you’re looking to start or advance your career in cloud infrastructure and DevOps, visit https://lnkd.in/gt6VMrbg to learn more.By investing in your education and mastering DevOps, you position yourself at the forefront of a growing field with endless opportunities.

Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? Share below! 👇 hashtag#CyberSecurityCareer hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#CyberSecTips hashtag#CareerGrowth) hashtag#cybersecurity hashtag#cybersecuritytraining hashtag#cybersecurityawareness hashtag#digitaltransformation hashtag#technology hashtag#digitalinclusion hashtag#innovation hashtag#informationsecurity

𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗔𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗘𝗻𝘁𝗿𝘆-𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗥𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀! 🚫We talk a lot about fixing hiring practices, yet one of the biggest flaws remains: requiring years of experience for entry-level roles.An entry-level role means just that—the starting point in someone’s career. If a position requires 2, 3, or even 7 years of experience, it’s not entry-level.Why This Needs to Change:✅ 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗱𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗯𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 and skills that can drive innovation.✅ 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 = 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 – Someone with years in the industry may not necessarily have the skills you need.✅ 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 – Labelling a job “entry-level” but demanding experience wastes applicants’ time and hurts your employer brand.✅ 𝗜𝘁 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 – Many qualified candidates self-reject because they don’t meet unrealistic requirements.🔹 Instead, set clear, realistic expectations: Entry-level = 0-1 year of experience.🔹 Focus on potential, skills, and learning ability rather than just past experience.🚀 If companies truly want to build strong, diverse, and future-ready teams, they need to 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆, 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆.Have you come across unrealistic job postings? Drop them in the comments! Let’s push for 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀. hashtag#EntryLevel hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#EntryLevelJobs hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#HRCommunity hashtag#WorkplaceInnovation hashtag#HiringTrends

Username: Africa ProCloud Institute Africa ProCloud Institute
Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. If you’re looking to start or advance your career in cloud infrastructure and DevOps, visit https://lnkd.in/gt6VMrbg to learn more.By investing in your education and mastering DevOps, you position yourself at the forefront of a growing field with endless opportunities.

Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? Share below! 👇 hashtag#CyberSecurityCareer hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#CyberSecTips hashtag#CareerGrowth) hashtag#cybersecurity hashtag#cybersecuritytraining hashtag#cybersecurityawareness hashtag#digitaltransformation hashtag#technology hashtag#digitalinclusion hashtag#innovation hashtag#informationsecurity

𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗔𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗘𝗻𝘁𝗿𝘆-𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗥𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀! 🚫We talk a lot about fixing hiring practices, yet one of the biggest flaws remains: requiring years of experience for entry-level roles.An entry-level role means just that—the starting point in someone’s career. If a position requires 2, 3, or even 7 years of experience, it’s not entry-level.Why This Needs to Change:✅ 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗱𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗯𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 and skills that can drive innovation.✅ 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 = 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 – Someone with years in the industry may not necessarily have the skills you need.✅ 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 – Labelling a job “entry-level” but demanding experience wastes applicants’ time and hurts your employer brand.✅ 𝗜𝘁 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 – Many qualified candidates self-reject because they don’t meet unrealistic requirements.🔹 Instead, set clear, realistic expectations: Entry-level = 0-1 year of experience.🔹 Focus on potential, skills, and learning ability rather than just past experience.🚀 If companies truly want to build strong, diverse, and future-ready teams, they need to 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆, 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆.Have you come across unrealistic job postings? Drop them in the comments! Let’s push for 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀. hashtag#EntryLevel hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#EntryLevelJobs hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#HRCommunity hashtag#WorkplaceInnovation hashtag#HiringTrends

Username: Africa ProCloud Institute Africa ProCloud Institute
Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. If you’re looking to start or advance your career in cloud infrastructure and DevOps, visit https://lnkd.in/gt6VMrbg to learn more.By investing in your education and mastering DevOps, you position yourself at the forefront of a growing field with endless opportunities.

Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? 𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗔𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗘𝗻𝘁𝗿𝘆-𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗥𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀! 🚫We talk a lot about fixing hiring practices, yet one of the biggest flaws remains: requiring years of experience for entry-level roles.An entry-level role means just that—the starting point in someone’s career. If a position requires 2, 3, or even 7 years of experience, it’s not entry-level.Why This Needs to Change:✅ 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗱𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗯𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 and skills that can drive innovation.✅ 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 = 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 – Someone with years in the industry may not necessarily have the skills you need.✅ 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 – Labelling a job “entry-level” but demanding experience wastes applicants’ time and hurts your employer brand.✅ 𝗜𝘁 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 – Many qualified candidates self-reject because they don’t meet unrealistic requirements.🔹 Instead, set clear, realistic expectations: Entry-level = 0-1 year of experience.🔹 Focus on potential, skills, and learning ability rather than just past experience.🚀 If companies truly want to build strong, diverse, and future-ready teams, they need to 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆, 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆.Have you come across unrealistic job postings? Drop them in the comments! Let’s push for 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀. hashtag#EntryLevel hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#EntryLevelJobs hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#HRCommunity hashtag#WorkplaceInnovation hashtag#HiringTrends

Username: Africa ProCloud Institute Africa ProCloud Institute
Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. If you’re looking to start or advance your career in cloud infrastructure and DevOps, visit https://lnkd.in/gt6VMrbg to learn more.By investing in your education and mastering DevOps, you position yourself at the forefront of a growing field with endless opportunities.

Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? Share below! 👇 hashtag#CyberSecurityCareer hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#CyberSecTips hashtag#CareerGrowth) hashtag#cybersecurity hashtag#cybersecuritytraining hashtag#cybersecurityawareness hashtag#digitaltransformation hashtag#technology hashtag#digitalinclusion hashtag#innovation hashtag#informationsecurity

𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗔𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗘𝗻𝘁𝗿𝘆-𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗥𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀! 🚫We talk a lot about fixing hiring practices, yet one of the biggest flaws remains: requiring years of experience for entry-level roles.An entry-level role means just that—the starting point in someone’s career. If a position requires 2, 3, or even 7 years of experience, it’s not entry-level.Why This Needs to Change:✅ 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗱𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗯𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 and skills that can drive innovation.✅ 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 = 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 – Someone with years in the industry may not necessarily have the skills you need.✅ 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 – Labelling a job “entry-level” but demanding experience wastes applicants’ time and hurts your employer brand.✅ 𝗜𝘁 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 – Many qualified candidates self-reject because they don’t meet unrealistic requirements.🔹 Instead, set clear, realistic expectations: Entry-level = 0-1 year of experience.🔹 Focus on potential, skills, and learning ability rather than just past experience.🚀 If companies truly want to build strong, diverse, and future-ready teams, they need to 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆, 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆.Have you come across unrealistic job postings? Drop them in the comments! Let’s push for 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀. hashtag#EntryLevel hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#EntryLevelJobs hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#HRCommunity hashtag#WorkplaceInnovation hashtag#HiringTrends

Username: Africa ProCloud Institute Africa ProCloud Institute
Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. If you’re looking to start or advance your career in cloud infrastructure and DevOps, visit https://lnkd.in/gt6VMrbg to learn more.By investing in your education and mastering DevOps, you position yourself at the forefront of a growing field with endless opportunities.

Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? 𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗔𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗘𝗻𝘁𝗿𝘆-𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗥𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀! 🚫We talk a lot about fixing hiring practices, yet one of the biggest flaws remains: requiring years of experience for entry-level roles.An entry-level role means just that—the starting point in someone’s career. If a position requires 2, 3, or even 7 years of experience, it’s not entry-level.Why This Needs to Change:✅ 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗱𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗯𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 and skills that can drive innovation.✅ 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 = 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 – Someone with years in the industry may not necessarily have the skills you need.✅ 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 – Labelling a job “entry-level” but demanding experience wastes applicants’ time and hurts your employer brand.✅ 𝗜𝘁 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 – Many qualified candidates self-reject because they don’t meet unrealistic requirements.🔹 Instead, set clear, realistic expectations: Entry-level = 0-1 year of experience.🔹 Focus on potential, skills, and learning ability rather than just past experience.🚀 If companies truly want to build strong, diverse, and future-ready teams, they need to 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆, 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆.Have you come across unrealistic job postings? Drop them in the comments! Let’s push for 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀. hashtag#EntryLevel hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#EntryLevelJobs hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#HRCommunity hashtag#WorkplaceInnovation hashtag#HiringTrends

Username: Africa ProCloud Institute Africa ProCloud Institute
Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. If you’re looking to start or advance your career in cloud infrastructure and DevOps, visit https://lnkd.in/gt6VMrbg to learn more.By investing in your education and mastering DevOps, you position yourself at the forefront of a growing field with endless opportunities.

Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? Share below! 👇 hashtag#CyberSecurityCareer hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#CyberSecTips hashtag#CareerGrowth) hashtag#cybersecurity hashtag#cybersecuritytraining hashtag#cybersecurityawareness hashtag#digitaltransformation hashtag#technology hashtag#digitalinclusion hashtag#innovation hashtag#informationsecurity

𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗔𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗘𝗻𝘁𝗿𝘆-𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗥𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀! 🚫We talk a lot about fixing hiring practices, yet one of the biggest flaws remains: requiring years of experience for entry-level roles.An entry-level role means just that—the starting point in someone’s career. If a position requires 2, 3, or even 7 years of experience, it’s not entry-level.Why This Needs to Change:✅ 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗱𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗯𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 and skills that can drive innovation.✅ 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 = 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 – Someone with years in the industry may not necessarily have the skills you need.✅ 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 – Labelling a job “entry-level” but demanding experience wastes applicants’ time and hurts your employer brand.✅ 𝗜𝘁 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 – Many qualified candidates self-reject because they don’t meet unrealistic requirements.🔹 Instead, set clear, realistic expectations: Entry-level = 0-1 year of experience.🔹 Focus on potential, skills, and learning ability rather than just past experience.🚀 If companies truly want to build strong, diverse, and future-ready teams, they need to 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆, 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆.Have you come across unrealistic job postings? Drop them in the comments! Let’s push for 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀. hashtag#EntryLevel hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#EntryLevelJobs hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#HRCommunity hashtag#WorkplaceInnovation hashtag#HiringTrends

Username: Africa ProCloud Institute Africa ProCloud Institute
Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. If you’re looking to start or advance your career in cloud infrastructure and DevOps, visit https://lnkd.in/gt6VMrbg to learn more.By investing in your education and mastering DevOps, you position yourself at the forefront of a growing field with endless opportunities.

Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? Share below! 👇 hashtag#CyberSecurityCareer hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#CyberSecTips hashtag#CareerGrowth) hashtag#cybersecurity hashtag#cybersecuritytraining hashtag#cybersecurityawareness hashtag#digitaltransformation hashtag#technology hashtag#digitalinclusion hashtag#innovation hashtag#informationsecurity

𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗔𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗘𝗻𝘁𝗿𝘆-𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗥𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀! 🚫We talk a lot about fixing hiring practices, yet one of the biggest flaws remains: requiring years of experience for entry-level roles.An entry-level role means just that—the starting point in someone’s career. If a position requires 2, 3, or even 7 years of experience, it’s not entry-level.Why This Needs to Change:✅ 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗱𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗯𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 and skills that can drive innovation.✅ 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 = 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 – Someone with years in the industry may not necessarily have the skills you need.✅ 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 – Labelling a job “entry-level” but demanding experience wastes applicants’ time and hurts your employer brand.✅ 𝗜𝘁 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 – Many qualified candidates self-reject because they don’t meet unrealistic requirements.🔹 Instead, set clear, realistic expectations: Entry-level = 0-1 year of experience.🔹 Focus on potential, skills, and learning ability rather than just past experience.🚀 If companies truly want to build strong, diverse, and future-ready teams, they need to 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆, 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆.Have you come across unrealistic job postings? Drop them in the comments! Let’s push for 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀. hashtag#EntryLevel hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#EntryLevelJobs hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#HRCommunity hashtag#WorkplaceInnovation hashtag#HiringTrends

𝗜𝗺𝗽𝗿𝗼𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗖𝗼𝗱𝗲 𝗤𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗔𝗻𝗮𝗹𝘆𝘀𝗶𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝗖𝗜/𝗖𝗗Maintaining a high-quality codebase and preventing technical debt is critical in any project. One effective way to achieve this is by integrating static code analysis into your CI/CD pipeline.Here’s how static analysis can help:✅ Early Bug Detection – Catches memory leaks, uninitialized variables, and null pointer de-references before they cause runtime issues. ✅ Performance Optimization – Identifies inefficient code, redundant computations, and unnecessary memory allocations. ✅ Security Improvements – Detects vulnerabilities like buffer overflows, improper input validation, and insecure cryptographic usage. ✅ Better Code Maintainability – Highlights unused variables/methods, enforces best practices, and keeps the codebase clean and readable. ✅ Consistent Coding Style – Ensures all developers follow the same coding guidelines, improving collaboration.Example of an implementation of Static Analysis in CI/CD:For a C++ project, I combined Clang-Tidy (to enforce modern C++ best practices) with CppCheck (for deeper bug detection).🔹 Local Script: Developers can run static analysis before committing code, example:https://lnkd.in/dpKpJxNZ🔹 CI/CD Integration: A GitHub workflow runs automated static analysis on every pull request, example:https://lnkd.in/de6XqWGBThis check can either block pull requests if errors are found or serve as a non-blocking quality tool while gradually improving the codebase.🚀 Have you integrated static analysis in your CI/CD pipeline? What tools do you prefer? hashtag#CICD hashtag#StaticAnalysis hashtag#CodeQuality hashtag#SoftwareEngineering

Username: Africa ProCloud Institute Africa ProCloud Institute
Post Content:
Why Companies Are Hiring a Lot of DevOps Engineers in 2025In 2025, the demand for DevOps engineers is soaring as organizations across industries recognize the pivotal role they play in modern technology environments. As the founder of Africa ProCloud Institute (APCI), I have witnessed firsthand the increasing need for skilled professionals who can bridge the gap between development and operations. Here’s why companies are aggressively hiring DevOps engineers this year.1. Unprecedented Cloud Adoption and ModernizationThe dominance of cloud computing platforms such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud has created a massive need for DevOps engineers. As more companies migrate to the cloud, they require professionals who can manage infrastructure, automate deployments, and maintain robust CI/CD pipelines. Hybrid and multi-cloud strategies have further amplified this demand, as seamless integration and operational efficiency become critical.2. Automation and Efficiency Are Non-NegotiableModern businesses thrive on efficiency, and DevOps engineers are masters of automation. Using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and Kubernetes, they transform manual, error-prone processes into automated workflows. Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) practices, championed by DevOps professionals, have become industry standards to accelerate software delivery and minimize risks.3. The Rise of DevSecOps for Enhanced SecurityWith cybersecurity threats at an all-time high, integrating security into the development process has become a priority. DevSecOps is the answer, embedding security practices within DevOps workflows. DevOps engineers who possess the ability to automate security measures are in high demand, helping companies safeguard their digital assets while maintaining agility.4. AI and Machine Learning Integration Demands ExpertiseArtificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are revolutionizing industries, and DevOps engineers play a crucial role in deploying these technologies. By building and maintaining complex data pipelines and streamlining deployment strategies, they enable organizations to harness the power of AI and ML effectively.At APCI, We’re Preparing the Next Generation of DevOps EngineersAt Africa ProCloud Institute, our mission is to equip students with the skills needed to thrive as DevOps engineers. Our accelerated programs cover critical technologies and best practices, ensuring our graduates are ready to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. If you’re looking to start or advance your career in cloud infrastructure and DevOps, visit https://lnkd.in/gt6VMrbg to learn more.By investing in your education and mastering DevOps, you position yourself at the forefront of a growing field with endless opportunities.

Cybersecurity Career: 7 Overlooked "Next Steps" (Beyond Certs and Tools) 1️⃣ Define Your Niche - Specialize: Don’t stay a generalist forever. Pick one path (e.g., cloud security, IoT pentesting, DevSecOps). - Business Alignment: Learn how your role impacts revenue, compliance, or risk (e.g., GDPR fines, ransomware mitigation). 2️⃣ Build a "T-Shaped" Skillset - Depth: Master 1-2 tools (e.g., Burp Suite, ELK Stack). - Breadth: Understand adjacent fields (e.g., DevOps for AppSec, finance for GRC). 3️⃣ Practice Deliberately - Labs > Certs: Prioritize HTB Pro Labs, OffSec PG Practice, or AWS security workshops over paper certs. - Blog Your Wins: Write up labs/CTF solutions—proves skills to employers. 4️⃣ Network Strategically - Find Mentors: Cold-message pros in your niche on LinkedIn. Most love sharing advice! - Join Hidden Communities: Smaller Discord groups (e.g., CTFtime, OSINT Framework) > generic forums. 5️⃣ Think Like an Adversary - Follow APTs: Study MITRE ATT&CK reports on groups like Lazarus or FIN7. - Break Things: Experiment with malware analysis (ANY.RUN sandbox) or reverse engineering (Ghidra). 6️⃣ Soft Skills Matter- Storytelling: Learn to explain risks to non-tech execs (e.g., "This vuln = $2M breach risk"). - Negotiation: Use sites like Levels.fyi to benchmark salaries for roles like Cloud Security Engineer. 7️⃣ Stay Hungry, Stay Ethical - Avoid Burnout: Cybersecurity is a marathon. Schedule learning and downtime. - Ethics First: Always align with frameworks like NIST or ISO 27001—reputation is everything. ---🔥 Pro Tips for Standing Out - Contribute: Fix a typo in OWASP docs? Add it to your resume! - Cert Stack: Pair technical (OSCP) + governance (CISSP) certs for leadership roles. - Job Hunt Hack: Target companies with public breaches—they’re hiring aggressively! 💬 Discussion Time! What’s the most underrated "next step" in your journey? 𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗔𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗘𝗻𝘁𝗿𝘆-𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗥𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀! 🚫We talk a lot about fixing hiring practices, yet one of the biggest flaws remains: requiring years of experience for entry-level roles.An entry-level role means just that—the starting point in someone’s career. If a position requires 2, 3, or even 7 years of experience, it’s not entry-level.Why This Needs to Change:✅ 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗱𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗯𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 and skills that can drive innovation.✅ 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 = 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 – Someone with years in the industry may not necessarily have the skills you need.✅ 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 – Labelling a job “entry-level” but demanding experience wastes applicants’ time and hurts your employer brand.✅ 𝗜𝘁 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 – Many qualified candidates self-reject because they don’t meet unrealistic requirements.🔹 Instead, set clear, realistic expectations: Entry-level = 0-1 year of experience.🔹 Focus on potential, skills, and learning ability rather than just past experience.🚀 If companies truly want to build strong, diverse, and future-ready teams, they need to 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆, 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘆.Have you come across unrealistic job postings? Drop them in the comments! Let’s push for 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗱𝘀. hashtag#EntryLevel hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#Hiring hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#EntryLevelJobs hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#HiringPractices hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#HRCommunity hashtag#WorkplaceInnovation hashtag#HiringTrends

𝗜𝗺𝗽𝗿𝗼𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗖𝗼𝗱𝗲 𝗤𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗔𝗻𝗮𝗹𝘆𝘀𝗶𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝗖𝗜/𝗖𝗗Maintaining a high-quality codebase and preventing technical debt is critical in any project. One effective way to achieve this is by integrating static code analysis into your CI/CD pipeline.Here’s how static analysis can help:✅ Early Bug Detection – Catches memory leaks, uninitialized variables, and null pointer de-references before they cause runtime issues. ✅ Performance Optimization – Identifies inefficient code, redundant computations, and unnecessary memory allocations. ✅ Security Improvements – Detects vulnerabilities like buffer overflows, improper input validation, and insecure cryptographic usage. ✅ Better Code Maintainability – Highlights unused variables/methods, enforces best practices, and keeps the codebase clean and readable. ✅ Consistent Coding Style – Ensures all developers follow the same coding guidelines, improving collaboration.Example of an implementation of Static Analysis in CI/CD:For a C++ project, I combined Clang-Tidy (to enforce modern C++ best practices) with CppCheck (for deeper bug detection).🔹 Local Script: Developers can run static analysis before committing code, example:https://lnkd.in/dpKpJxNZ🔹 CI/CD Integration: A GitHub workflow runs automated static analysis on every pull request, example:https://lnkd.in/de6XqWGBThis check can either block pull requests if errors are found or serve as a non-blocking quality tool while gradually improving the codebase.🚀 Have you integrated static analysis in your CI/CD pipeline? What tools do you prefer? hashtag#CICD hashtag#StaticAnalysis hashtag#CodeQuality hashtag#SoftwareEngineering
